Description: Limestone stela of Djehutyhermaktef: round-topped stela divided into two sections decorated in sunk relief with incised texts. In the upper register the hawk-headed Re‘-Harakhty is seated in a solar barque together with a baboon representing Thoth on his left offering an 'wedjat'-eye to the god. The second register consists of ten columns of text which contain a prayer to Re‘ on behalf of the workman Djehuthermaktuf who is depicted kneeling in adoration in the left-hand corner of the stela. The upper and lower right-hand corners of the stela have been lost and restored in modern times. The surviving upper register is badly worn in places. There are extensive traces of orange paint on the figures in both registers and in the hieroglyphs.
Curator's comments: Djehuthermaktuf, son of Nebdjefau, is a well-attested member of the community of Deir el-Medina in the early part of the reign of Ramses II. A list of his monuments can be conveniently consulted in K. A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside inscriptions : translated & annotated Translations Vol.3, Ramesses II, his contemporaries' (Oxford, 2000), 839-44 and G. Andreu, ‘Bulletin de l’Institut Français d’Archéologie Orientale’ 85 (Cairo, 1985), 1-21. His wife is named as the lady Werner, and she can be identified as the adult female on this lintel. The young girls are thus the daughters of Djehuthermaktuf, although not attested elsewhere. Because of the reference to 'son' in the description of Djehuthermaktuf, this piece probably comes from the tomb of his father Nebdjefau. Bibliography: The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 137 (no. 486); B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' I (2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), ii, 718; K. A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside inscriptions : translated & annotated Translations Vol.3, Ramesses II, his contemporaries' (Oxford, 2000), 841; G. Andreu, ‘Bulletin de l’Institut Français d’Archéologie Orientale’ 85 (Cairo, 1985), 14.
Bibliographic references: Hall 1925 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 7. (pl.37)
Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.46-47)
Condition: The upper and lower right-hand corners of the stela have been lost and restored in modern times. The surviving upper register is badly worn in places. There are extensive traces of orange paint on the figures in both registers and in the hieroglyphs.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
